div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

FRIDAY, AUGUST 4, 1905.
THE KAISER’S MOVEMENTS.

There seems to be good reason to believe that the Kaiser’s visit to Copenhagen is con- nected with the candidature of Prince Charles of Denmark for the vacant throne of Norway. It has been stated by some of the best informed French journals that the Emperor William, realising that a Hohenzollern would find some difficulty in accommodating himself to the democratic institutions of Norway, has decided to suggest that Prince Charles should accept the Norse Crown, should it be offered him. The suggestion that a Prince of the House of Glucksborg should rule in Norway, which was for two centuries under the Danish Crown, was likely to be revived with great satisfaction by both Danes and Norwegians, and was certain to be opposed by Russia, whose Government had reasons for objecting to any arrangement that might bring about the formation of a Scandinavian League. Russia’s movement towards the open water, whether at the Varanger Fiord, the Dardanelles, Bandar Abbas, or Alexandretta, is certain to be re- sumed, as soon as the disasters of the Japanese war have been forgotten by the public, which has probably last as short a me- mory as every and any other public, the German excepted. When and if the Slavs move forward to the open water in the west they do not wish to find their way blocked by a league of small bat well-orga- nised Powers, and the choice of a Prince descended from the last Danish King of Norway and popular in Sweden, would be of great service in smoothing down the ruffled a feelings of Sweden and Norway, the first step to the creation of a defensive alliance—a new northern league.

The Kaiser, according to our French con- freres, approves of this scheme. A Scandinavian synthesis may one day form part of the larger Teutonic synthesis of which he dreams, and by offering his high protection and imperial guarantee against foreign aggression to the three small Powers, he hopes to strengthen the good relations between Norway and Sweden on the one side, and Germany on the other, and to give Denmark cause to forget the devasta- tion of Jutland and the loss of Schleswig- Holstein. The project is attractive enough ; Sweden was believed, a few years back, to be on the point of entering the Triple Alliance, and the Kaiser’s yachting exploits—his game book contains the entry of a whale, slain no doubt with one of the Hohenzollern’s 1.9 inch quickfirers aimed by the Imperial sportsman— and his gift to the burnt out Aalesunders

have made him popular in Norway. There is Russia to consider, however, and Russia is in a terribly bad humour and must have a sugar plum to keep her quiet! But the Kaiser means Russia to have her Atlantic port, Lyng Fiord near Tromso. Norway need not be nervous, she will give up a harbour for a consideration, and gain the protection of Kaiser Wilhelm and no doubt two friendly allies, and Russia and Germany and the Scandinavian Powers will all live happily ever after. But what if Norway declines to part with Lyng Fiord ?
FOREIGN AFFAIRS IN FRANCE.

The Committee of the Chamber of Deputies on Foreign Affairs, of which M. Paul Deschanel is the president, has adopted the report of M. Francois Deloncle on the defence of the colonies and of the colonial sub-commission of the extra-Parliamentary naval commission. It has decided to recommend to the Government a common plan of action in Indo-China for the three departments of war, the navy, and the colonies, according to which unity of defence shall be assured by placing the authority in the hands of the Governor-General. General Voyron will probably be sent out to inspect the Indo-Chinese native troops, and an elabor- ate inquiry will be undertaken into the policy now being applied in the treatment of the native populations. The credits necessary to render the Saigon arsenal capable of affording shelter and of serving as a completely-equipped naval station for the French fleet will be asked for by the Foreign Affairs Committee.

As regards French relations with China, this committee urges a revision of the Franco- Chinese commercial treaty, as well as of those between China and Indo-China; the develop- ment in China of French Universities like that of Cheng-tu ; the conclusion with England of agreements permitting the common con- struction of a network of Chinese railways, particularly the lines of the Yang-taze, Han- kau-Cheng-tu, and those of the two Kwangs ; and the solidarisation (sic) of French and English interests in China and in the Far East, so as to guarantee to both Powers the main- tenance of their territorial status quo in Chinese seas.

The same committee expresses its desire for the establishment of closer economic rela- tions between France and Japan, and for a direct commercial convention between Japan and Indo-China. It also advises an agree- ment with England to urge Siam to abandon her plan of armaments and to effect a real neutralisation of the Menam Valley.

On the Abyssinian question the decision of the Foreign Affair Committee is to assure Menelik that France is resolved to respect the integrity of Abyssinia, and, until that country has been neutralised by general agreements, to insist, first, that the Djibouti-Dire Daouah line shall remain under French national con- trol ; secondly, that the Imperial Company of Ethiopian Railways shall be pat in a posi- tion to enjoy to the fall the rights belonging to it by virtue of the concession of 1894.

The improvement of the points d’appui of Dakar and Diego Suarez and the reinforcement of the army of occupation in Madagascar also form part of this striking programme adopted by the Foreign Affairs Committee, and now placed before the public in a letter from M. Paul Deschanel to the Premier. It is the evidenoe of a vigilance to which hitherto the foreign affairs committee of the French Cham- ber had not accustomed us, and in the general drift of its recommendations it shows once again how deeply-rooted the idea of the entente with England has become in France.

div.head: THE WAR.
IMPORTANT STATEMENT BY M. WITTE.
div.p: RUSSIAN REVERSES MINIMISED.
New York, August 3.

M. Maartens read the reporters on the quay a statement of M. Witte, hoping that the acquaintance of two chivalrous foes, begun on the battlefield, will ripen into a lasting friend- ship, but Russia must adjudge the terms offered as admissible before proceeding with formal negotiations. The Tsar’s acceptance of Pre- sident Roosevelt’s invitation, involving the unusual course of the appointment of a mission before the enemy’s terms had been even out- lined, is an eloquent token of the friendly feel- ings of Russia towards the United States. It was in consequence of the desire to strengthen this friendship that the Tsar accepted the invitation. Even if the mission be otherwise barren, this will remain a memorable event for Russia and the United States.

M. Witte, interviewed during the voyage, minimised the importance of the Russian reverses. The Japanese have not yet acquired such supremacy as to make Russia consider them a truly redoubtable enemy. They would have to advance four times as far before they would be in a position to impose terms. The internal situation of the country will in nowise affect the question of peace. The majority of Russians regard the war as simply a distant colonial struggle not threatening the security of the country. He himself strongly favored peace, but the Japanese must be convinced that peace is in nowise indispensable to Russia, who will never accept conditions even appar- ently offending her amour propre. (Reuter.)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: The Brindisi Mail will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 3.15 p.m. on Monday.
Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Ghezireh district of Cairo during the night of Saturday and at daybreak on Monday will be poisoned by the police.
Suez Canal. —12 vessels passed through the Canal on the 1st inst., of which 7 were British, 2 German, 1 Danish, 2 Dutch. The day’s receipts were frs. 320,667.33.
The Opera Season.—The Societe Artisti- que d’Egypte has secured the rights of pro- duction of Mascagni’s latest opera Amica, for the next Cairo and Alexandria opera season.
New Hospital.—We understand that the next meeting of the legislative Council, which will be held to-morrow, will consider the ques- tion of the construction of a new hospital at Abbassieh.

The Plague.—To-day’s bulletin records three fresh cases at Alexandria, of which two were fatal. The first is a native boy, who is the nephew of the woman who was found dead at Bab Sidra Barrani yesterday, the second was a native boy who was found dead at his home in the Toubgieh esheshes, and the third was a native girl who was found dead at Farahda. A death in hospital is reported from Dekerness.

Fire at Esneh.—Esneh was the scene of a troublesome fire on Tuesday. The shop of an Arab named Bomed Suleiman took fire,and the flames spread to several of the neighbouring shops, where great damage was done. The fire brigade had to work bard for 24 hours before the conflagration was under control, and the damage done to buildings and property is naturally very considerable.

Mummified Cats.—Whilst some workmen were pulling down an old cottage at Filey a mummified cat in perfect preservation was discovered between the top ceiling and the roof. An Egyptologist places the age of the mummy at 200 years. A week or two ago a somewhat similar find was made in another old building. The latest discovery, which has : its “whisker” bristles perfect, is to be forward- ed to the British Museum.

Nile Service.—Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son (Egypt), Limited, have issued their programme of sailings from Cairo for the Nile during the forthcoming season. We note that the first steamer to leave for Luxor and the First Cataract will be the Rameses III., on Tuesday, November 14. There will be twenty-four sailings from Cairo, the last being from Cairo on March 6. The Second Cataract service will commence with the departure of the Prince Abbas from Shellal on December 10, in connection with the tourist steamer from Cairo on November 28. The express steamers will leave Cairo twice a week during the season, on Fridays and Mondays at 4.30 p.m. The Friday afternoon departures will com- mence on November 3 and the Monday depar- tures on December 4.

Old Bourse Palace Bar.—We are informed by Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi, Limited, that their Old Bourse Palace Bar will be open- ed to the public to-morrow evening at 7 o’clock. The bar has been most sumptuously and artistically fitted up at enormous cost since the recent fire, and is a great improvement on the old bar, which was in itself one of the finest establishments of the kind to be found out of Europe. Customers will find that their every comfort and convenience has been studied. Besides the bar, a tea- room has been fitted up, and cold and hot luncheons and suppers will be served. Cus- tomers will also find all kinds of newspapers and magazines, and those desirous of tele- phoning to Cairo may make use of the special instrument on the premises. Another feature will be the reception of telegrams from New York giving the dosing prices of the cotton market Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi wish us to add that at their stores in Old Bourse- street there is now always to be found a supply of fresh Findon haddocks, bloaters, herrings, and salmon.

div.head: THE YEMEN RISING.
HOW SANA FELL
div.p: (From our Correspondent).
Suez, Thursday.
The following information has been given me by a Turkish officer who was a prisoner at Yemen in the insurgent camp during the siege of Sana.

When Sana was surrounded by the insur- gents, all communication was cut off, and the capital suffered considerably being short of provisions. The insurgents had captured six guns from the Turks in a previous battle. These they placed in position to bombard Sods, but not knowing how to use them, they compelled a Turkish officer, whom they had taken prisoner, to bombard the town.
At first, the officer purposely directed the shells over the town and in other directions, but being found out, he was ordered by his captors to keep his aim on the town, or else he would be shot.
The siege lasted for over a fortnight, and the surrounded Turks Buffered terrible hard- ships, having nothing to eat for many days. They at last surrendered the town to the insurgents.

div.head: THE TROUBLES IN CRETE.
div.p: The following General Order by the General Officer Commanding the Force in Egypt was issued yesterday:—

The General Officer Commanding here by de dares that, by reason of the recent existence of active service in the Island of Crete, it is necessary for the public service, in his opinion, that the British Forces serving in that Island should be temporarily subject to the Army Act as if they were on active service. And he further declares them to be so subject to the Army Act as from the 31st July, 1905, inclusive, and until such date as may be sub sequently announced in General Orders.”

div.head: QUARANTINE IN GREECE.
div.p: A telegram from Athens states that hence- forth arrivals from Alexandria and Adalia will be submitted to a rigorous medical inspection.

div.head: FAYOUM ELECTRIC LIGHTING
div.p: The Fayoum Local Commission has, for some time past, been contemplating the installa- tion of electric plant, driven by water power, for the lighting of the town, and for the purpose of supplying current to the various factories in the bandar. It appears that the project is now about to be realised. The Com- mission is negotiating on the subject with several companies, who wish to utilise the waterfalls situated about six miles from the town,which are said to be capable of furnishing 850 horse power.
One of the conditions of the contract will be that the concessionnaire will have to put up 300 electric lamps for the lighting of the streets.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.
div.p: Further reports received by the secretary of the local board in Cairo, respecting the results obtained by the exploratory party in Northern Khargeh, show that the official in charge is satisfied that water abounds near the surface, and can be found whatever it is required in that district. The water is said to be of excellent quality, inferior to none so far obtained in the Oasis. Arrangements are being made for the continuation of the work of opening the sub- terranean water channels at Kasr-el-Gyp.

div.head: NEW AFRICAN COMPANY
SATISFACTORY REALISATIONS MADE.
div.p: The eleventh ordinary general meeting of the members of the New African Company, Limited, was held on the 27th ulto. at the Can- non Street Hotel, London, E.C., under the presidency of the Rt. Hon. the Earl of Ches- terfield, P.C.
The Secretary (Mr. Thomas Day) read the notice convening the meeting and the report of the auditors.

The Chairman : Gentlemen, although, as you are aware, depression still reigns so for in the South African markets, the board are glad to report that the prospects of all our chief assets have considerably improved, whilst, owing to our extended business in Africa generally, we have been able to effect some satisfactory realisations permitting the distributions which we recommend this year. (Applause.) It will hardly be necessary for me to dwell at any length upon the balance-sheet, which I think is sufficiently dear. In December last an issue of 20,547 shares was made at £2 per share, bringing the issued capital up to its present figure of £390,397. Of this number 14,144 shares were subscribed for by the shareholders, and the balance of 6,403 were taken up by the guarantors of the issue. The balance-sheet has been made up to Jan 30th last, in order to be in line with the companies with whom we are working in association. We have adopted this year a more simple plan of dealing with the accounts by showing only the realised profits and extinguishing the items of appreciation and depreciation. As we have stated, the market price of the assets quoted on the Stock Exchange and a moderate valuation of those which are not at present ready for marketing show an excess in value considerably over the amount appearing in the balance sheet (Ap- plause.) It has, of course, been impossible for us to do much in South Africa of a profitable nature. The reasons are only too well known to you, and as it is not in our power to shape the course of the South African market we can only wait patiently for the better times which are bound sooner or later to set in. The market mast in course of time respond to the increas- ing output of the Rand now that it is provided with ample labour. We have,however, had much good fortune with the Welgedacht Com- pany, where, upon the advice of our engineers, we commenced boring on the eastern portion of the form, and have located the reef at a much shallower depth with a good assay value. The new survey plans are now before the Commissioner of Mines, and new certifi- cates are expected immediately. What is equally satisfactory is that we have experienced on the Welgedacht property one of those lucky episodes which are such a familiar feature in South African mining history. I refer to the enormous coalfield which has been proved to exist on the Welgsdacht farm, which contains, according to the estimate of our engineers, no less than 15,000,000 tons of coal, of a quality equal if not superior, to the best coal found in the Springs district. Shafts are now being sunk to open up the seams, and an equipment is being provided for an output of 20,000 tons of coal per month, capable of being increased to 40,000 tons per month. I think, gentlemen, we can congratulate ourselves on the satisfactory development of the Welgedacht form daring the year under review. With regard to the New South Rand, you re- ceived last year particulars as to the objects of this company, and in accordance therewith boring has been proceeded with energetically, and, as we have informed you, the hole has now reached a depth of 3,301 ft. Here again we mast trust to mining lack as to whether or not the possibilities described by our engineers can be realised. Our agency at Johannesburg has in the meantime been constantly occupied with the examination of other mining pro- perties, one of which, a copper property, we hope we shall have the opportunity of bringing before yon next year, under conditions which, we trust, will be of considerable advantage to this company. We have also to record the most important foot that henceforth, owing to the arrangements made with the Beira Railway Company, Beira, the capital of the territory, is to become the port of entry for Rhodesia. Hitherto, as you are perhaps aware,for reasons which it is unnecessary for me to go into here, the port of Beira was starved by the high railway rates, and the traffic of Rhodesia, which ought to have come naturally to Beira, mainly went through Port Elizabeth and Cape Town. We expect that with the reduced railway rates the traffic of Beira will be doubled, and you will not be slow to realise the importance those new arrangements will have upon the activity of the town, upon its trade, and upon the position of the Mozambique Company generally, and no doubt, as we hope, this will reflect in due course most favorably on the holding which, with the Oceana Company and others, we possess in the Mozambique Company. During the course of the year Sir Thomas Holditch, K.C.M.G, whose name is no doubt well-known to you, has become president of the united committees of the English and French members of the board, which are working in the most cordial way with the Portuguese directors in doing all that is possible to develop and improve the Mozambique Company’s territory. The agricultural experiments on which we dwelt last year tend to show that cotton-growing may become one of the staple industries of the country. Indeed, the experiment made by the Oceana Company and ourselves are very encouraging As there is a large quantity of land available for cotton grow- ing, we hope we have given a start to an industry which alone should render the territory of the Mozambique Company of considerable value. In the meantime it is satisfactory to

know that the current African expenditure of the Mozambique Company was very little in excess of the receipts, even in such a bad year as 1904, and thus we can reasonably hope for profits from the further resources of the huge territory which so far have hardly been touch- ed. You will receive shortly the report of the Mozambique Company, which is of an exhaustive nature and which will give you the fullest particulars of this interesting enterprise. The next asset to which I will now refer is out indirect interest, through the Inter- national Ethiopian Railway Trust, in the Ethiopian Railways, of which you have no doubt seen much mention in the Press during the past year. We have informed you from year to year of the desire of our group, in conformity with the wishes of the Emperor Menelik, to internationalise the Abyssinian system of railways, somewhat inadequately described in our report as the “Djibouti- Harrar Railway.” At the same time we desired to respect such special rights as the French Government, with the consent of the Emperor Menelik, are entitled to by reason of the subsidy of £20,000 per annum, granted to the Ethiopian Railway Company in 1902. As you will have gathered from the report, we have every reason to hope that suitable arrangements will shortly be completed with due advantage to the stock held in the enterprise. This matter is engaging the daily attention of your man- agers in London and Paris, and this company is to be congratulated on having been able, by its influence, to contribute to the desired solu- tion. I now come to Egypt, where, as we told you last year, we expected to make favorable realisations, and this we have been able to do. The business of the New Egyptian Company, which has been built up with so mnch care during the last few years, has now reached a stage of successful development, which has enabled it to realise some of its important land assets. The New Egyptian Company itself will shortly be issuing its annual report, which we will also distribute amongst you, as we did last year. This will give you full and interest- ing particulars of its progressing business. As to our interests in West Africa, the result has indeed been extremely favorable. The Abosso Company, with 20 stamps only, is now turning out some £9,000 to £10,00 worth of gold per month, and the Taquah mine, belong- ing to the Taquah and Abosso Company, is also opening up with very favorable indica- tions. Here, again, we have assets the potential values of which are much above the present market price, as, indeed, is the case with most of our chief assets. In the Marconi Wire- less Company, which we are helping to finance with our other associated companies, great pro- gress has been made in the establishment of wire- less telegraphy on sea and land, and the resnlts of the long-distance apparatus across the Atlantic are such that we can hope that next year re- gular communication will be open for public use at rates much below those charged by the cable companies. Your directors, therefore, consider the investment you have in this con- cern, which we will continue to follow with financial help when required, shows every prospect of good returns I need not detain you with reference to the many other matters which have occupied the attention of your board, bat the most interesting is a mining business in Australia which we are developing under the guidance of our consulting en- gineers, Messrs. Alexander Hill and Stewart. The results so for have been very satisfactory, and warrant the business being incorporated in a company which will shortly be formed to work the mine. You will see that, in spite of the heavy fall in prices, especially in South African mining shares, we have, thanks to our varied assets, been able to show satis- factory results : and, having regard to the favorable nature of our interests, we think, when the markets improve, we can reasonably look forward to a great improvement in the value of our holdings, and distribute larger dividends than the one which we have the pleasure to recommend to you to-day. I now beg to move the adoption of the report and accounts.
Baron de Chevreliere seconded the motion, and it was carried unanimonsly.
The retiring director (Lord Chesterfield) and the auditors (Messrs. Cooper, Brothers and Co.) having been reappointed, the pro- ceedings terminated with a vote of thanks to the chairman.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
BATHING AT RAMLEH.
div.p: Dear Sir,—I am pleased to see that at last someone is making complaints about the disgraceful state of things along the Ramleh shore. Some time ago I took a house near the sea expressly for my children, and looked forward to spending many happy and healthy hours on the beach. We had no garden and we could not afford carriages and trams every day. I can only say that after two visits to the particularly nice sandy beach, where we had hoped to gather the lovely shells and paddle, etc., nothing would have induced us to return. The place was nothing less than a public latrine. This was a long way from the bay “Mermaid” mentions. It was also im- possible to go for walks along the beach in the cool of the evening, as we were followed and insulted by low-class Greeks and Italians. I have heard the same complaints from many.— I am. A Respectable Woman.
Ramleh, August 3.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Edward Cecil Pasha will probably return to Cairo to-morrow.

Mr. Webb, acting Adviser to The Ministry of Public Works, returned to Cairo this morning from Assouan, where he has been paying a visit of inspection in connection with the strengthen- ing of the reservoir.
Mr. P. Machell, who is staying at San Stefano, leaves for Cairo to-morrow.
Fathi Bey Zegloul, President of the Cairo Native Court of First Instance, is expected to return from leave on the 17th inst.
It is stated that Kaimakam Khalif Bey Khairi will probably replace the late Hassan Bey Sadik as commandant of the Khedivial Guard.
Mr. A. H. Hooker, general manager of the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Limited, is expected book from England at the beginning of September.
Leave for 3 1/2 months has been granted to Tobia Bey Kamel, chief inspector to the Ministry of Finance, to date from the 1st instant.

div.head: THE SOLAR ECLIPSE.
div.p: Among the scientific missions which will watch the eclipse of August 30, is that under the command of M. Janssen, head of the famous Meudon observatory, who, as long ago as 1868, invented the methods of observing eclipses that are generally employed to-day. M. Janssen’s mission will watch the eclipse from Valencia, in Southern Spain.

div.head: THE COMPTOIR NATIONAL.
div.p: The Comptoir National d’Escompte de Paris opens its new agency at Alexandria on the 7th inst. For the present, the offices of the Comptoir National are installed on the first floor of the Antoniades Building, Cherif Pasha- street. They will be transferred to the ground floor as soon as the necessary changes in the building, which are in course of completion, have been carried through.

The Comptoir National’s capital amounts to frs. 150,000,000, all paid up. It has 40 branches in Paris, 111 in France, and many others in London, Manchester, and Liverpool, in Morocco and Tunis, the East Indies, Australia and Madagascar. Its excellent or- ganisation enables it to meet the financial and commercial needs of Alexandria under the best possible conditions.
The manager of the agency is Mr. Pierre Llewellyn. Messrs G. J. Buissiez and Henry Pougin are sub-managers. Mr. Edouard Savig- non has fall powers in all share and bourse transactions. 28802-3-1

div.head: BRITISH NAVAL VISIT TO THE BALTIC.
Program of the Cruise.
div.p: Arrangements have been made for the Channel Fleet, with the First Cruiser Squa- dron, to visit the Baltic at the conclusion of the fetes at Portsmouth on the occasion of the visit to England of the French squadron. Admiral Sir Arthur Wilson will sail from England about August 15, and will be accom- panied, it is understood, by eleven first-class battleships and five armoured cruisers. The other admirals who will take part in this most interesting cruise are Vice-Admiral Sir Arthur Moore, formerly a Lord of the Admiralty and now second in command of the Channel Fleet; Rear-Admiral Sir Richard Poore, and Rear- Admiral George Neville, the last-named having recently taken over the control of the Cruiser Squadron. Nothing in the nature of “official visits,” writes a Naval Correspondent, "is contemplated, as the cruise is undertaken in the ordinary routine of the fleet’s sea-training.”

The size of this great naval force cannot fail to make a great impression in the Baltic. It is many years since a large British fleet visited the Baltic, and consequently the advent of the ships of Admiral Sir Arthur Wilson is calculat- ed to excite much attention in Europe. On the other hand, the absence of visits by British men-of-war has been due to no conditions such as apply to the Black Sea. The Baltic is an open sea to the fleets of the world ; it is as free to the ships of the Great Powers as is the Mediterranean, the Atlantic, the North Sea, or the English Channel.

A visit from the Channel fleet will be espe- cially welcome to the peoples of Denmark, with which our country is so intimately connected, and of Scandinavia, who have had no oppor- tunity for many years of seeing any units of the British Navy, it is natural that the war- ships most frequently seen in these waters should be those of Russia and Germany. Thir- teen battleships of the latter Power have lately been cruising in the Baltic, a fact all the more noticeable now that the Russian fleet has suffered such grievous losses.

The British cruise in the Baltic is, in a sense, a return visit, though there will be a complete absence of formalities. On two occasions in recent years German squadrons have enjoyed the hospitality of our ports. Prince Henry of Prussia, it will be remembered, after cruising to the north of the British Isles, put into the British naval base at Berehaven, on the Irish coast,and was visited by the Duke of Connaught while occupying the familiar anchorage of the Channel Fleet. Later on—in 1904, in fact— squadron made a few days’ stay at Plymouth, where the German officers and men were enter- tained, and were permitted to go over the local dockyard ; while as recently as this spring the German Emperor paid a visit to Gibraltar. We have also had calls from Russian squadrons. Admiral Baron von Stackelberg was at Portland two or three years ago with a powerful force then on its way to Port Arthur, but only formal courtesies were exchanged, as the stay was purely for the purpose of coaling the ships and resting the crews.

It will be seen from the programme of the cruise that the Channel Fleet is not to visit any German or Russian naval ports, but will anchor in ordinary commercial harbours of the smallest size. Ymuiden, the first port of call, is a little place of 2,000 inhabitants on the Dutch coast, about six miles from Haarlem, and at the end of the North Sea Canal. The British ships will afterwards make a stay at a small harbour near Esbjerg, which is a Danish seaport on the south-west coast of Jutland, and thence put into Swinemunde, which is thirty-seven miles north west of Stettin, finally visiting the Prussian anchorage of Neufahr- wasser, a northerly suburb of Dantzig. The Fleet will cross to Scotland and proceed to the Shetland Islands after the cruise in the Baltic.
The programme is as follows :
Arrive Leave
–– Spithead. Aug. 15
Aug. 16 Ymuiden (Holland) Aug. 19
Aug. 20 Gras Deep (for Esbjerg). Aug. 23
Aug. 28 Swinemunde (Stettin). Aug. 31
Sept. 1 Neufahrwasser (Dantzig). Sept. 4
Sept. 9 Invergordon (Scotland). Sept. 15
Sept. 16 Lerwick (Shetlands). —

Between Aug. 23 and Aug. 28 the Channel Fleet will anchor as convenient in the Katte- gat or Great Belt, and also on the return voyage between Sept 4 and Sept 9. The Montagu will probably be detached from the Channel Fleet at Invergordon to refit

div.head: COTTON AT THE IMPERIAL INSTITUTE
div.p: The West India Committee held a reception on the 26th ulto. at the Cotton-Growing Ex- hibition in the Imperial Institute. A large number of cotton brokers and others interested in the trade were present. Special prominence was given to the St. Kitts cotton exhibit. The West Indian Islands were formerly almost ex- clusively engaged in cotton planting, the ex- port in 1801 amounting to 10 million pounds ; in 1901 it had fallen to 280,000 pounds, although St. Kitts cotton commands the highest price in the market.

An effort, it was stated, is now being made to produce a cheaper kind, in order to compete with the mainland American cotton. The culti- vation of cotton is again on the increase, some 14,000 acres being now devoted to it, as against 400 in 1902.

div.head: FRIDAY NIGHT IN BEVIS MARKS SYNAGOGUE.
A QUAINT CORNER OF LONDON.
div.p: In Bevis Marks, a corner of the City that meets the boundary line of the East-End, commerce rules life from dawn to dusk. This afternoon the narrow streets are crowded with eager pushing men of business vans loaded with merchandise lumber along the cobbled ways; often in the charge of lads whose nerve must be a special product of London streets. Bevis Marks and its environs are given over seemingly to Eastern produce, to the wares of Japan, China, India, Persia, and the Levant; to all the spices and colours and subtleties of the Orient Between the shops, redolent if not reminiscent of the East, a gateway gives entrance to a courtyard cobbled with well- worn stones, and in the centre of the court is a great grey building, worn by two centuries of London weather, stained by as many years of London’s dust and dirt. It is Bevis Marks Synagogue, built in the year 1701 A.D., or, according to Jewish date, in the year 5462, a venerable house of prayer, lull of memories whose interest extends beyond the lives of the Sephardic Jews. Here Isaac d’lsraeli, father of Lord Beaconsfield, and author of “Curiosities of Literature," worshipped until the "Gentle- men of the Mahamad” worried him from the fold; here, in his turn, Sir Moses Montefiore was called up to the Law many a time and oft, and gave freely for the benefit of the poor in acknowledgment of the honor; here many men, whose descendants have passed, into the noblest families of the land and for- gotten their nationality and faith, were to be seen on Fridays and Sabbaths and festivals. The merchant princes of Jewry, the men whose advice and assistance were sought in the Cabinets of the Georges, worshipped regularly at Bevis Marks ; their homes were in streets not far removed from the synagogue, in Great Prescott-street, Mansell-street, Alie street, and others unheard of now. Dutch, Spanish, Portuguese, or Italian, they spoke Spanish in their homes and recited Hebrew with an accurate pronunciation, lived quiet lives amid surroundings reminiscent of their earlier homes, and avoided assimilation, either with non-Jews or German Jews, with a horror that was in no wise assumed.

This afternoon the ancient synagogue reveals beggarly array of empty benches. Service is . about to begin—first the service of the after- noon, then the service of the Sabbath. In times past the courtyard would have been thronged with worshippers, the women’s galleries would have been crowded ; this afternoon there are few more than a score of people in the precincts of the synagogue. The big brass candelabra serve still to illumine the scene the undying light of the silver lamp illumines the Ark where the scrolls of the Law are kept. Even the beadle, whose gold braid is curiously sugges- tive of bygone days when it was in keeping with its surroundings, his lost much of his importance ; his services are unclaimed ; he has authority but there is none on whom to exercise it.

Yet though the old synagogue of the Spanish and Portuguese Jews has fallen from its high estate, it still affords a restfulness that few synagogues can grant The worshippers are devout, the candles soothe eyes tormented by electric or incandescent gas light, the noise of the streets is subdued, the restless City may be forgotten here.

The Chazan is unconscious of the paucity of his congregation; he is content to have ten males of more than thirteen years, the num- ber required by the Law. As he proceeds with the service, assisted by the small choir and the vigorous responses of the congregants, the light in the synagogue becomes more clear, for evening is setting in, and the candles are freed from the competition of the daylight. Now and again, at some pause in the service, a van rattles down the stony street beyond the syna- gogue walls, but the succeeding silence atones for the interruption.

I recognise in my fellow-congregants a class of worshippers seldom or never met in the synagogues of the town’s West-end. In Bevis Marks, and to a lesser degree in the Chevras the consecrated rooms scattered about little known streets of the East end, one notes a devotion spontaneous and unconscious, finds its nearest counterpart outside synagogue in the worship of Islam. The remnant of a once powerful community has met here to greet the Sabbath, “as a bridegroom welcomes his bride.” The labours of the week are over, the worries of business are laid aside, the wor- shippers hurried to the synagogue, they will go slowly home. Some have fallen out of line in account of poverty, or on account of pros- terity, the remnant lingers, larger than it looked to be when service started.

In the vestry rooms beyond the synagogue there are tablets bearing the names of de- parted congregants who held high office or gave largely of their goods to the poor, and no great effort is needed to people the empty benches with the brilliant assembly that often graced them in the eighteenth century. Marrano Jews from Spain, entitled to bear inns, diplomats to their finger tips, feeling their way cautiously in a strange land; others who passed from Palestine into the Barbary States, thence into the Iberian Pe- ninsula, and thence to Holland, where they benefited by the intercession of Manasseh ben Israel with Cromwell. There were some who came from Palestine to England by way of the Levant, and made a brave show in the early days of their sojourn here, playing a prominent part in the world’s affairs modestly, and with a complete lack of the ostenta- tion that marks so many of the community hailing from Russia, Poland, and Germany.

Service is over. The small congregation gathers from the shadows that engulf it, and makes slow way to the outer court, with Sabbath wishes for its friends. I see one or two very old men who were born when the name of the great Napoleon was still common in men’s mouths, while Bevis Marks was yet the Metropolis whereunto all that was best in Jewry assembled. They still speak Spanish one to another, and inquire about the family of friends dead a generation since. “He was of the old school,” they say respectfully, and make their way with un- certain steps into the busy city beyond the synagogue gate. They too are of the old school, though they know it not, and far down the Mile End-road, where the City has run its course and Greater London rules, the rest of the men and women who comprised that school are asleep in the “House of Life,” to which the last few survivors will soon be gathered.

div.head: THE SHEET ANCHOR.
BY BARTIMEUS
div.p: The gorse, scattered about in yellow dumps on the hillsides, caught the last glow of setting sun and transformed the landscape into a patchwork of green and gold. High up on the hills, the smoke of smouldering peat fires curled up into the still air, staining the pale turquoise of the sky with countless plumes of grey.

In grim contrast to the peaceful scene, squadron of battleships lay at anchor under the shadow of the hills, behind which the sun had new set. They lay in two lines, towering above the surface of the water in sullen, frowning majesty, the grinning muzzles of their guns peeping out along their sides in silent witness of latent might, like the un- sheathed claws of a sleeping lion. A cutter, her blue clad crew pulling with swift, powerful strokes, left the shore, and broke the surface with a wedge-shaped ripple ; in the distance she resembled some huge, many-legged insect moving across the bay ; a fish rose and fell back with a splash, and the sun caught the drops of water and transformed them into a shower of liquid fire.

The report of a rifle rang out from the bridge of the flagship, and the blare of bugles echoed across the water as the White Ensign crept slowly down from its staff at the stern of each ship, in obedience to the “Sunset” signal. One by one the colours faded from the western sky ; the blue changed to deep violet, the crimson to dull purple, and pre- sently the stars began to appear in the dark euing heavens. A gentle breeze sprang up, just ruffling the surface of the water, and then died away in a whisper. The moon rose over the hills, casting its reflection along the bay in a track of shimmering radiance, against which the dark hulls of the men-of-war were silhouetted and distinct, like ebony upon a silver background.

A lurid streak of flame shot out from one of the flagship’s batteries, and the “boom” of a 12-pounder startled the sleeping gulls into shrill cries of alarm as the mournful notes of the “Last Post” rose on the night air. There was an infinite sadness in that volume of music which rose and swelled and died away in plaintive cadence among the hills, echoing and re-echoing, until it sank to a distinct whisper, and silence fell once more on the anchored fleet. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

Aft on the quarterdeck the lieutenant of the middle watch was pacing slowly to and fro. A bell amidships struck the hour, and he walked yawning to the gangway, and peered out into the darkness. A stiff breeze had sprung up, and angry little white-capped waves were racing past in jagged lines of spray, to vanish again into the gloom astern.

The anchor lights of the men-of-war seemed to blink drowsily as the ships swung slowly on the tide, and the shrill cry of a storm-driven gull rose above the whistling of the wind. He turned and glanced anxiously at the awning overhead: a gust, fiercer than the rest, caught it, and the huge stretch of canvas bellied and creaked ominously.
“Quartermaster !”
“Sir !” A muffled figure appeared from the lee of a casemate and saluted.
“Go and wake the Commander, and ask him if I may furl the awning, as it’s coming on to blow.”
Presently the Commander appeared, keen- eyed, alert, and resourceful.
He stepped briskly to the side and looked over the rails into the blinding smother of driving spray and rain ; then turning, he gave a curt order.
Down on the warm, dimly-lit mess-deck, a steady chorus of snores proceeded from rows of closely-packed hammocks. Suddenly the notes of a bugle rang out, followed by the shrill twitter of a pipe :
“Clear lower deck, hands furl quarter-deck awning ! ’

The snores stopped and gave place to the murmur of voices, as the half-awakened men tumbled hastily out of their hammocks in obedience to the summons. Bluejackets, ma- rines, and stokers poured on deck in a stream of profane, jostling humanity, pulling on their clothes as they ran.

In the centre of the quarter-deck stood the Commander, his collar turned up and his hands in his jacket pockets. He glanced quick- ly round and gave a crisp order. The pipes twittered and the ropes that held the awning were eased in.
"Let go ! Haul over !”

Then began a battle royal. The wind caught it, and flung it into the air, buffeting men to and fro, as a terrier shakes a swarm of rats. The rain poured down, adding to the misery of the sleepy, struggling men, and soaking them to the skin. Now and again from the chaos of hauling figures and sodden, flapping canvas the voice of a lieutenant rose in cheery encouragement, and at last the struggle finish- ed, and the awning was furled and safely stowed away.

In the meanwhile the officer of the watch was forward on the upper bridge, bending anxiously over the electric-lit binnacle. He was taking the bearing of the flagship’s anchor- light; for a minute he stood motionless, his cap crammed down on his head, and his eyes glued to the little mirror, while the wind hum- med through the shrouds with a sound like the wailing of lost souls. Then he straightened up and swore softly under his breath, for the bearing of the other ship’s lights was slowly changing.
He hurried down the ladder, and met the captain in the battery.
“We are dragging a little, Sir.”
“Sheet anchor ready for letting go !”
“A1 ready, sir.”
They stepped on to the forecastle, when the full force of the gale met them and drove the

rain into their faces with blinding fury. A little group of men was visible in the darkness, tending by the sheet anchor, the light of a lantern glancing fitfully on to their wet oilskins and bronzed faces.
“Stand clear. Let go !”

A man stepped back a pace and swung a hammer; it knocked up a lever, and the chains hat held the anchor were released. Down it went to its bed ten fathoms beneath the sur- face, with a roar of cable and a splash that sent the spray flying over their heads, while the long, dear notes of the boatswain’s-mate “piped down” the hands.
Outside the galley a bluejacket wiped the rain from his face with a horny palm, and raised a mug of steaming cocoa to his mouth.
“We ain’t got much money,” he remarked cheertully, “but we do see life.”

div.head: Theatre Alhambra
div.p: La troape italienne de Comédie “Délia Guardia" dirigée par le Chev. Andrea Maggi débutera demain soir avec Fedora dé Sardon. Cette troape se compose de très bons élé mente. Le saocès qae Mme Clara délia Guardia- et M. Andrea Maggi ont recueilli partout en Italie et dernièrement à la Commanda de Milan justifient pleinement nos meilleures pré- visions.
Il faut reconnaître que M. Conegliano a cette fois-oi le mérite d’avoir engagé une troupe qui compte parmi les premières d’Italie.
La navigation fluviale

Le nouveau projet de règlement sur la navi- gation fluviale, que le gouvernement prépare actuellement, se divise en deux parties : l’une technique relevant du ministère des travaux publics ; l’autre, comprenant la police de la navigation, regarde le ministère de l’intérieur-

Toute personne, pour faire naviguer un bateau à vapeur sur le Nil ou les canaux, devra au préalable avoir obtena l’autorisation du ministère des travaux publics et cette auto- risation ne sera accordée qu’après épreuves satisfaisantes des chaudières, moteurs, co- que, etc.
Le remorquage sera interdit à proximité des ponts et des écluses et d’une façon générale sur les canaux.
Des prescriptions spéciales régleront les questions de détail relatives à la navigation.
Le ministère des travaux publics désignera par un arrêté les canaux navigables.
Les propriétaires de bateaux seront respon- sables des dégâts que pourront subir de leur fait les ouvrages d’art établis sur le Nil ou les canaux.
Comme nous le disons fins haut la partie relative à la police de la natation sera régle- mentée par le ministère de 1 ntérieur.
Informations finanoieres
Crédit Foncier Egyptien

La souscription aux 263819 obligations 3 % de Fcs. 500, du Crédit Foncier Egyptien, qui a eu lieu à Paris le 25 Juillet dernier,a obtenu, ainsi qu’il était facile de le prévoir, un très brillant succès ; elle a été oouverte sept fois.
Les derniers joumanx arrivés d’Europe di- sent qae la Société Générale à elle seule a recueilli des souscriptions à 1,100,000 obliga- tions, soit pins de trois fois la totalité de l’émission.
Les cours d’assises
La prochaine session de la Cour d’assises du Caire s’onvrira le 12 de ce mois.

Le 13 comparaîtra devant elle, sous l’incul- pation d’homicide involontaire, le jeune chauf- feur indigène qui, il y a environ deux mois, ramenant au garage l’omnlbus-automobile fai- sant alors la navette entre fa ville et fa brasse- rie des Pyramides à Guizah, tamponna nne femme indigène en état d’ivresse près du rond- point de Tewfilrieh.

Le lendemain, oe sera le tour d’Andraons Meloka et de ses oomplices, inculpés du vol de fa sourrah du Mahmal, et le même jour ou le lendemain, de Léon Fahmy, accusé de tenta- tive de chantage à l’égard de Mohamed Paoha Orphi.

div.head: Municipalité d'Alexandrie
AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication l’em- pierrement de trois rues à l’Ibrahimieh.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 35.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau de fa Voirie où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exoeptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l’Administrateur de fa Mu- nicipalité avant le 15 Août 1905.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séanoe de fa Délégation le même jour à 5h.p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre fa men- tion: “Soumission pour l’empierrement des trois rues à l’Ibrahimieh.”

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Servi oe de la Comptabilité Générale avant l’ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 15 Août 1905 à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
Le Vice-Président,
(signé) Ambroise A. Ralli.
Alexandrie, le 3 Août 1905. 26304-8-1
AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication l’em- pierrement et fa construction de fa canalisation de fa rue Chatby.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 50.
Le aahier des charges est déposé au Bureau de fa Voirie où il peut être oonsulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exoeptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l’Administrateur de fa Municipalité avant le 22 Août 1905.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de fa Délégation le même jour à 5h.p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre fa men- tion : “Soumission pour l’empierrement et canalisation de fa rue Chatby.”

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de fa Comptabilité Générale avant l’ouvertnre des offres et au plus tard le 22 Août à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions oi-dessus sera écartée.
Le Vice-Président
(Bigné) Ambroise A. Ralli.
Alexandrie, le 3 Août 1905. 26305-3-1
